questions.question_html:
Evaluate.

Determine two mixed numbers, with different denominators, that have the following properties.

a sum of 3\frac{4}{5}
questions.question:
Determine two mixed numbers, with different denominators, that have the following properties.

a sum of `$3\frac{4}{5}$`
questions.answer_html: Answers may vary e.g. 2\dfrac{3}{10} + 1\dfrac{1}{2}

questions.question_html:
Which of the following is the right steps to show the work for below:

Why is 3\frac{2}{5} - 1\frac{4}{7} the same as \frac{3}{7} + 1\frac{2}{5}?
questions.question:
Which of the following is the right steps to show the work for below:

Why is `$3\frac{2}{5} - 1\frac{4}{7}$` the same as `$\frac{3}{7} + 1\frac{2}{5}$`?
questions.answer_html:
3\frac{2}{5} - 1\frac{4}{7}

= 3 + \frac{2}{5} -1 -\frac{4}{7}

= 3 -1 + \frac{2}{5} -\frac{4}{7}

= 2 -\frac{4}{7} + \frac{2}{5}

= 1 + 1 -\frac{4}{7} + \frac{2}{5}

= 1 -\frac{4}{7} + 1 + \frac{2}{5}

= \frac{3}{7} + 1 \frac{2}{5}

questions.question_html:
Recalculate 3\frac{1}{4} - 1\frac{1}{2} by following the steps below.

i. Find the difference between the whole parts.

ii. Subtract the fraction in the first mixed number from the fraction in the second mixed number.

iii. Subtract the answer in part (ii) from the answer in part (i).

**ii.** Subtract the fraction in the first mixed number from the fraction in the second mixed number.

**iii.** Subtract the answer in part (ii) from the answer in part (i).

questions.question_html:
Which of the following is the right steps to show the work for below:

Why is 3\frac{2}{3} - 1\frac{5}{6} the same as 3\frac{5}{6} - 2?
questions.question:
Which of the following is the right steps to show the work for below:

Why is `$3\frac{2}{3} - 1\frac{5}{6}$` the same as `$3\frac{5}{6} - 2$`?
questions.answer_html:
3\frac{2}{3} - 1\frac{5}{6}

=3+ \frac{2}{3} - 1- \frac{5}{6}

=3+ \frac{2}{3} - 1- \frac{5}{6} + +\frac{5}{6} - \frac{5}{6}

=3 +\frac{5}{6}+ \frac{2}{3} - 1- \frac{5}{6} - \frac{5}{6}

=(3 +\frac{5}{6})+ (\frac{2}{3} - 1- \frac{5}{6} - \frac{5}{6})

=(3 +\frac{5}{6})+ (-2)

=3\frac{5}{6}-2

questions.question_html:
There are \displaystyle 3 \frac{3}{4} c of flour, \displaystyle 1 \frac{1}{2} c of sugar, \displaystyle \frac{2}{3} c of brown sugar, and \displaystyle \frac{1}{4} \mathrm{c} of oil in a cake mix. How many cups of ingredients are there in all?

A \displaystyle 4 \frac{1}{2} \mathrm{c}

C \displaystyle 5 \frac{1}{2} \mathrm{c}

B \displaystyle 5 \frac{1}{6} \mathrm{c}

D \displaystyle 6 \frac{1}{6} \mathrm{c}

questions.question_html: Without calculating the quotient, how do you know that 4\frac{2}{3} \div 10\frac{1}{4} has to be less than \frac{1}{2}?
questions.question: Without calculating the quotient, how do you know that `$4\frac{2}{3} \div 10\frac{1}{4}$` has to be less than `$\frac{1}{2}$`?
questions.answer_html:
Since half of 5\frac{1}{8}

and 4\frac{2}{3} < 5\frac{1}{8},

therefore 4\frac{2}{3} \div 10\frac{1}{4} < \frac{1}{2}

questions.question_html:
(a) Evaluate each power: (-2)^2, (-2)^3, (-2)^4, (-2)^5

(b) Examine the signs of your answers. What pattern do you notice?

(c) Explain how you can tell the sign of the answer when a power has a negative base. Create and use examples of your own to illustrate your explanation.
questions.question:
**(a)** Evaluate each power: `$(-2)^2, (-2)^3, (-2)^4, (-2)^5$`

**(b)** Examine the signs of your answers. What pattern do you notice? 

**(c)** Explain how you can tell the sign of the answer when a power has a negative base. Create and use examples of your own to illustrate your explanation.
questions.answer:
a) 4, -8, 16, -32

b) When the exponent is odd, the power is negative, and
when the exponent is even, the power is positive.

c) Negative bases will give a positive answer if the
exponent is even {`$ (-1)^2 = -1 \times -1 = 1$`} and a negative answer if the exponent is odd 

{`$ (-1)^3 = -1 \times -1 \times -1 = -1$`}
questions.answer_html:
a) 4, -8, 16, -32

b) When the exponent is odd, the power is negative, and when the exponent is even, the power is positive.

c) Negative bases will give a positive answer if the exponent is even { (-1)^2 = -1 \times -1 = 1} and a negative answer if the exponent is odd

{ (-1)^3 = -1 \times -1 \times -1 = -1}

questions.question_html:
Find the error in each solution. Explain what was done incorrectly. Redo the solution, making the necessary

\begin{array}{llll} &-2(3)^2; \text{ step 1}\\ &= (-6)^2; \text{ step 2}\\ &= 36; \text{ step 3} \end{array}

Both Claire and Robin calculated 5(-2) -3(-2). Clare's calculations

Clare's calculations

\begin{array}{c} &5(-2) -3(-2) \\ &= -10 + 6 \\ &= -4 \\ \end{array}

Robin's calculations

\begin{array}{c} &5(-2) -3(-2); \text{ step 1 }\\ &= 2(-2); \text{ step 2 }\\ &=-4; \text{ step 3 }\\ \end{array}

Both students are correct. Explain Robins' reasoning from step 1 to 2.
questions.question:
Both Claire and Robin calculated `$5(-2) -3(-2)$`.
Clare's calculations

Clare's calculations

`$
\begin{array}{c}
&5(-2) -3(-2) \\
&= -10 + 6 \\
&= -4 \\
\end{array}
$`

Robin's calculations

`$
\begin{array}{c}
&5(-2) -3(-2); \text{ step 1 }\\
&= 2(-2); \text{ step 2 }\\  
&=-4; \text{ step 3 }\\ 
\end{array}
$`

Both students are correct.   Explain Robins' reasoning from step 1 to 2.
questions.answer:
Let `$x = -2$`

so step 1 is equal to `$5x - 3x$`

which is equal to `$2x$` which then is equal to step 2.
questions.answer_html:
Let x = -2

so step 1 is equal to 5x - 3x

which is equal to 2x which then is equal to step 2.

\begin{array}{c} &-4[5- 2(-3)]; \text{ step 1 }\\ &= -4[3(-3)]; \text{ step 2}\\ &= -4[-9]; \text{ step 3}\\ &= 36; \text{ step 4 }\\ \end{array}
questions.question:
Find the error in each solution.  Explain what was done incorrectly.   Redo the solution, making the necessary 

`$
\begin{array}{c}
 &-4[5- 2(-3)]; \text{  step 1 }\\
&= -4[3(-3)]; \text{ step 2}\\
&= -4[-9]; \text{ step 3}\\
&= 36; \text{ step 4 }\\
\end{array}
$`

questions.question_html: Assume b and n are positive integers. When n is an odd number, decide whether -b^n +(-b)^n is positive, negative, or zero. Explain your reasoning.
questions.question: Assume `$b$` and `$n$` are positive integers.  When `$n$` is an odd number, decide whether `$-b^n +(-b)^n$` is positive, negative, or zero.   Explain your reasoning.
questions.answer: Negative. If `$n$` is odd, then both `$-b^n$` and `$(-b)^n$` would have negative values. When you add two negative values, the answer would be negative.
questions.answer_html: Negative. If n is odd, then both -b^n and (-b)^n would have negative values. When you add two negative values, the answer would be negative.

questions.question_html: Assume b and n are positive integers. When n is an even number, decide whether -b^n +(-b)^n is positive, negative, or zero. Explain your reasoning.
questions.question: Assume `$b$` and `$n$` are positive integers.  When n is an even number, decide whether `$-b^n +(-b)^n$` is positive, negative, or zero.   Explain your reasoning.
questions.answer: Zero. If `$n$` is even, then `$-b^n$` would be negative and `$(-b)^n$` would be positive. The magnitudes of the numbers would be equal, so the values would be opposites. The sum of two opposite numbers is zero.
questions.answer_html: Zero. If n is even, then -b^n would be negative and (-b)^n would be positive. The magnitudes of the numbers would be equal, so the values would be opposites. The sum of two opposite numbers is zero.

questions.question_html: Which of the following correctly explains 3\frac{1}{5} - 2\frac{1}{4} has the same answer as \frac{3}{4} + \frac{1}{5}?
questions.question: Which of the following correctly explains `$3\frac{1}{5} - 2\frac{1}{4}$` has the same answer as `$\frac{3}{4} + \frac{1}{5}$`?
questions.answer_html:
3\frac{1}{5} - 2\frac{1}{4}

=3+\frac{1}{5} - 2-\frac{1}{4}

=3-2 +\frac{1}{5} -\frac{1}{4}

=1 +\frac{1}{5} -\frac{1}{4}

=\frac{1}{5}+ 1 -\frac{1}{4}

=\frac{1}{5}+ (1 -\frac{1}{4})

=\frac{1}{5}+ \frac{3}{4}

=\frac{3}{4} + \frac{1}{5}

spaced in the cupboard. How much space is above or below each shelf?

#2719

questions.question_html: Suppose the on screen cursor represents any numeric character. Determine the number of numeric characters that can fit on the calculator screen.
questions.question:
Suppose the on screen cursor represents any numeric character. Determine the number of numeric characters that can fit on the calculator screen.


#298639
questions.answer: `$1\dfrac{3}{8} \div \dfrac{11}{64} =8$` rows and `$2 \div \dfrac{1}{8}=16$` characters per row. `$8 \times 16 = 128$` characters.
questions.answer_html: 1\dfrac{3}{8} \div \dfrac{11}{64} =8 rows and 2 \div \dfrac{1}{8}=16 characters per row. 8 \times 16 = 128 characters.

b) -64

c) -49

d) -1331
